newsitem.title: USA: Evans & Sutherland to roll out 3D systems.
newsitem.headline: Evans & Sutherland to roll out 3D systems.

text.p: Evans & Sutherland Computer Corp will on Tuesday unveil its Universal 3D Architecture aimed at bringing three-dimensional graphics to an industry standard platform, company executives said.

They said ahead of the launch that sophisticated 3-D graphics that were once only available on Unix-based systems, such as those of industry pioneer Silicon Graphics Inc, will now be available on machines based on Microsoft Corp's Windows NT software and Intel Corp's microprocessors.
The software includes Harmony, the company's new high-end product, which is being demonstrated at the I/TSEC military technology trade show in Orlando, Florida on Tuesday.
The company is also unveiling Integrator NT, a database tool for producing and managing synthetic environments.

The company's REALimage product for the desktop market was unveiled in August, and all three products were used in a demonstration by Intel Chief Executive Andy Grove during his Comdex trade show keynote address last month.
REALimage is available now in sample quantities, with volume production due in the first quarter of 1997 at a street price of $2,000, while Harmony systems start at $150,000
